awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Novel Textile Based Sensors for Inner Prosthetic Socket Environment Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
Amputation is one of the major causes of disability. Sockets are the important prosthesis components and physical interface to integrate the prosthetic limbs mechanically with the amputee's residual limb to replace lost function. Objective monitoring of the inner socket environment (i.e. pressure, temperature, and humidity) and residual muscle activity during daily prosthesis use requires flexible, unobtrusive and multi-modal sensors that can be integrated into the socket structure without causing subject discomfort. The lack of such an inner-socket sensor technology has been a long-standing problem for evaluating the prosthesis socket, preventing the complications elicited by poor socket design and fit, and advancing the socket technologies. Therefore, advanced socket technologies are urgently needed and will be developed under this project to significantly reduce the number of clinic visits, lower the healthcare costs for amputees, and ultimately improve their quality of life. The impacts of this project will reach far beyond the immediate scientific and engineering contributions that result from it. The use of technologies to further understand the capability of textiles as sensing elements; to design novel systems to monitor the health; and to increase comfort and gait function of amputees in new ways, all provide priceless opportunities to motivate and educate younger generations, their educators and the public-at-large towards the future advancements in manufacturing and biomedical sensing innovation. 

This project aims to develop a novel Flexible InneR-socket Sensing Technology (FIRST) to be seamlessly, unobtrusively, and elegantly integrated into the lower-limb prosthesis socket. FIRST is based on an electronic-fabric structure where the fibers of the fabric act as sensory elements and could simultaneously track tactile forces, moisture/wetness, electromyography and body temperature at multiple sensing points around the residual limb. In particular, the focus of this project is to enable these soft textile-based sensors to address the relevant challenges in the context of wireless inner socket environment monitoring.The major challenge and overarching objective of this research is to develop a fundamental understanding of the coupling and interaction between multi-component fiber cross-sectional architecture, fabric structure, and its electro-mechanical response to achieve a multimodal sensor that can be unobtrusively integrated into 'textile-based' sensory devices in general.  We will evaluate the multiple sensing capabilities of FIRST on patients with lower limb amputations inside and outside of a laboratory environment. The interpretation of FIRST data would identify locations of skin problems to enable patient-self management and allow for a more objective clinical evaluation to avoid the occurrence of potential skin breakdown and the resulting complications.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing textiles integrated sensor systems to monitor the inner environments of the lower-limb prosthesis sockets. Fiber based sensors were embedded into electronic-textile fabric structures for multi-modal and simultaneous monitoring of important physical parameters such as tactile forces and moisture/wetness at multiple sensing points around the residual limb within the socket.

The project team is composed of interdisciplinary researchers from the fields of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Biomedical Engineering, and Fiber and Polymer Science under Textile Engineering as well as medical doctors and prosthetics developers. Three different systems were developed and tested on human subjects to demonstrate the intellectual merit of this project: 

  1. Fiber sensors using a custom-designed 3D printer system: Uniquely shaped conductive polymer fibers with diameters in the order of 100s of micrometers were 3D printed and woven into sensor arrays to monitor the normal pressure in inner socket environments. The analysis of the data of these performed experiments with human amputee subjects showed promising results where these fiber-based sensors integrated within the prosthetic environment were able to detect variation in pressure within the prosthetic limb during walking. 

  2. Bi-component fiber sensors manufactured using melt extrusion and custom designed extrusion spin-pack. A novel fabrication method and unique fiber cross-section with a resolution of 100s of nanometers and fiber diameter of a few micrometers was developed. The team studied the fibers? ability to sense changes in pressure and developed several methods to improve the sensor performance by altering the geometry of the fiber assembly. As a proof-of-concept demonstration, the fibers were woven into a pressure- sensing mat consisting of sixty-four sensing elements. The preliminary testing demonstrated that the woven substrate was able to detect the location and level of pressure.

  3. Low cost, textile embedded sensing using commercially available seamlines woven as capacitive structures within prosthetic liner structures. This method targeted textile embedded capacitive pressure sensors and impedance based wetness sensors using a traditional sewing process and two orthogonal conductive sewing yarns (silver-plated polyamide and stainless steel) insulated with cotton, polyethylene-terephthalate (PET) and elastomeric meltblown textile dielectrics. The team performed experiments using a 36 element sensor array on amputee subjects wearing prosthetic adapters demonstrating promising results. 

 

The broader impact of this project is in its potential to offer a soft textile-based sensor solution for real-time monitoring of the inner socket environment in order to help patients and clinicians to avoid the occurrence of potential skin breakdown and the resulting complications affecting millions of amputee subjects around the world. The results of the project were shared with the public through more than 20 peer reviewed publications and 6 Ph.D. thesis dissertations. Two press releases, two best-poster awards (Flexible and Printed Electronics Conference and Society for Biomaterials Conference) and a patent was generated as an outcome of this project. The research team also mentored more than 50 undergraduate and high school students during the course of this project. 

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2022
Modified by: Alper Y Bozkurt

This project focused on developing textiles integrated sensor systems to monitor the inner environments of the lower-limb prosthesis sockets. The analysis of the data of these performed experiments with human amputee subjects showed promising results where these fiber-based sensors integrated within the prosthetic environment were able to detect variation in pressure within the prosthetic limb during walking. 


Bi-component fiber sensors manufactured using melt extrusion and custom designed extrusion spin-pack.
